docs.lead_paragraph: A reader calls for an educational campaign about vaccines.

docs.lead_paragraph: Certain disease-causing variant genes became more common in African-Americans after their ancestors reached American shores, scientists report.

headline.seo: Genome Research Points to Adaptation Among Early African-Americans
headline.main: Genome Study Points to Adaptation in Early African-Americans
headline.print_headline: Genome Study Points to Adaptation in Early African-Americans

docs.abstract: Study published in journal Genome Research finds that certain disease-causing variant genes became more common in African-Americans after their ancestors reached America, while others, such as the gene for sickle cell hemoglobin, have become less common; researchers, led by Li Jin of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, suggest certain genes may have proliferated because they conferred secondary, offsetting benefits.
docs.snippet: Certain disease-causing variant genes became more common in African-Americans after their ancestors reached American shores, scientists report.

docs.lead_paragraph: Eric Lander, the head of the Broad Institute, went from the most solitary of sciences (math) to forging collaborations on the leading edge of biology, a field he never formally studied.

headline.seo: Broad Institute Director Finds Power in Numbers

docs.abstract: Profile of Eric Lander, mathematician who went on to become a founding director of the interdisciplinary Broad Institute of Harvard and MIT, where he presides over a veritable empire of biological research.
docs.snippet: Eric Lander, the head of the Broad Institute, went from the most solitary of sciences (math) to forging collaborations on the leading edge of biology, a field he never formally studied.

docs.lead_paragraph: IF you want to know what is wrong with American health care today, exhibit A might be the two new proton beam treatment facilities the Mayo Clinic has begun building, one in Minnesota, the other in Arizona, at a cost of more than $180 million dollars each. They are part of a medical arms race for proton beam machines, which could cost taxpayers billions of dollars for a treatment that, in many cases, appears to be no better than cheaper alternatives. Proton beam therapy is a kind of radiation used to treat cancers. The particles are made of atomic nuclei rather than the usual X-rays, and theoretically can be focused more precisely on cancerous tissue, minimizing the danger to healthy tissue surrounding it. But the machines are tremendously expensive, requiring a particle accelerator encased in a football-field-size building with concrete walls. As a result, Medicare will pay around $50,000 for proton beam therapy for a patient with prostate cancer, roughly twice as much as it would if the patient received another type of radiation.

headline.main: It Costs More, but Is It Worth More?

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by doctors Ezekiel J Emanuel and Steven D Pearson criticizes rush by major medical institutions to construct expensive proton beam facilities for cancer treatment; contends that in most cases proton beam therapy is no more effective than traditional radiation therapies for many cancers; proposes that Medicare should refuse to pay for procedure except where there is valid evidence that it is clinically superior to other treatments. Drawing (M)
docs.snippet: IF you want to know what is wrong with American health care today, exhibit A might be the two new proton beam treatment facilities the Mayo Clinic has begun building, one in Minnesota, the other in Arizona, at a cost of more than $180 million dollars...

headline.main: It Costs More, but Is It Worth More?

docs.abstract: Before paying for an expensive cancer treatment, Medicare should demand evidence that it’s more effective than cheaper options.
docs.snippet: Before paying for an expensive cancer treatment, Medicare should demand evidence that it’s more effective than cheaper options.

They are part of a medical arms race for proton beam machines, which could cost taxpayers billions of dollars for a treatment that, in many cases, appears to be no better than cheaper alternatives.

headline.main: It Costs More, but Is It Worth More?

docs.abstract: Before paying extra for an expensive cancer treatment, Medicare should demand evidence that it's more effective.
docs.snippet: Before paying extra for an expensive cancer treatment, Medicare should demand evidence that it's more effective.

byline.original: By EZEKIEL J. EMANUEL and STEVEN D. PEARSON

docs.lead_paragraph: Responding to experiments in the Netherlands and the United States in which scientists created a highly transmissible form of the potentially deadly H5N1 bird flu virus, the National Science Advisory Board for Biosecurity urged scientific journals not to publish details of the work out of fear that the information could be used by terrorists. Laurie Garrett, senior fellow for global health at the Council on Foreign Relations and a recipient of a 1996 Pulitzer Prize for her coverage of an Ebola epidemic, responds to questions about the public policy implications of bird flu and bioterrorism. Her latest book, "I Heard the Sirens Scream," offers a detailed account of the 2001 anthrax attacks and the bioterrorism policy actions that resulted.

headline.main: A Public Policy Expert Looks at the Bird Flu Threat

docs.abstract: Laurie Garrett of the Council on Foreign Relations talks about bioterrorism and the public policy implications of a deadly bird flu threat.
docs.snippet: Laurie Garrett of the Council on Foreign Relations talks about bioterrorism and the public policy implications of a deadly bird flu threat.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the battle to lose weight, and keep it off, our bodies are fighting against us.
docs.abstract: Tara Parker-Pope article highlights research done by University of Melbourne professor Dr Joseph Proietto on obesity, which was published in The New England Journal of Medicine and has caused a stir in the weight-loss community; Proietto and his colleagues have found that the human body continues to fight against weight loss long after dieting has stopped, and adds to a growing body of evidence that challenges conventional thinking about obesity.
docs.snippet: In the battle to lose weight, and keep it off, our bodies are fighting against us.
